question: What are the average improvements of the proposed \\frameworkname~method compared to baselines in terms of ranking metrics and portfolio-based metrics?
answer: The proposed \\frameworkname~method achieves averagely 13% improvements on ranking metrics and 47% improvements on portfolio-based metrics compared with all baselines.
reference: \\frameworkname: Market-Guided Stock Transformer for Stock Price Forecasting, section \"Conclusion\": \"Experiments on the Chinese market with $2$ stock universe shows that \\frameworkname~achieves averagely $13\\%$ improvements on ranking metrics and $47\\%$ on portfolio-based metrics compared with all baselines.\"

question: How does \\frameworkname~perform in the CSI800 dataset compared to the XGBoost baseline in terms of the Excess Annualized Return (AR) metric?
answer: In the CSI800 dataset, \\frameworkname~achieves an AR of 0.28±0.02, which shows a significant improvement over the XGBoost baseline that has an AR of 0.08±0.02.
reference: \\frameworkname: Market-Guided Stock Transformer for Stock Price Forecasting, \"Table \\ref{tab:performance}\": \"... & XGBoost & $0.040 \\pm 0.000$ & $0.37\\pm 0.01$ & $0.047\\pm 0.000$ & $0.42\\pm 0.01$ & $0.08\\pm 0.02$ & $0.6\\pm 0.2$  ... \\frameworkname~ & \\bm{$0.052^*\\pm0.006$}  &... & \\bm{$0.28^*\\pm0.02$} & \\bm{$2.3^*\\pm0.3$}  ...\"

question: What were the details of the datasets used in the experiments of the DPA-STIFormer?
answer: The experiments were conducted on four datasets: CSI500, CSI1000, NASDAQ, and NYSE. The CSI500 had 3159 samples and 500 nodes, divided into 2677 training, 239 validation, and 243 test samples. The CSI1000 had the same number of samples but 1000 nodes. The NASDAQ dataset had 1225 samples and 1026 nodes, divided into 738 training, 253 validation, and 234 test samples. Similarly, the NYSE dataset had 1225 samples and 1737 nodes, with the same partitioning as NASDAQ.
reference: \"Double-Path Adaptive-correlation Spatial-Temporal Inverted Transformer for Stock Time Series Forecasting\" - Section: EXPERIMENTS, Table: The overall information for datasets.

question: How did the DPA-STIFormer perform compared to other models on the CSI500 and CSI1000 datasets in terms of IC and A_RET?
answer: On the CSI500 dataset, the DPA-STIFormer achieved an IC of 0.1312 and an A_RET of 0.8721. On the CSI1000 dataset, it achieved an IC of 0.1404 and an A_RET of 1.2703. These results indicate that the DPA-STIFormer outperformed other models such as FC-LSTM, which achieved an IC of 0.1193 and an A_RET of 0.5357 on CSI500, and MTGNN, which achieved an IC of 0.1176 and an A_RET of 0.4614 on CSI500.
reference: \"Double-Path Adaptive-correlation Spatial-Temporal Inverted Transformer for Stock Time Series Forecasting\" - Section: Main Results, Table: Comparison results on four datasets.

question: What is the average performance improvement of the GINN model over the GARCH model, as well as other baseline models, in terms of prediction accuracy according to the paper \"GARCH-Informed Neural Networks for Volatility Prediction in Financial Markets\"?
answer: The GINN model is on average 5.81% better than the GARCH model, 22.72% better than the GJR-GARCH model, 18.79% better than the TGARCH model, and 22.05% better than the LSTM model in terms of prediction accuracy across the datasets tested.
reference: Reference: \"GARCH-Informed Neural Networks for Volatility Prediction in Financial Markets\", Section 4 Results. \"The GINN model is $5.81\\%$, $22.72\\%$, $18.79\\%$, and $22.05\\%$ better than the GARCH model, the GJR-GARCH model, the TGARCH model, and the LSTM model, respectively, on average.\"

question: How many days of daily closing values were used for training and testing each model in the paper \"GARCH-Informed Neural Networks for Volatility Prediction in Financial Markets\"?
answer: Approximately 7,500 days of daily closing values were captured for each model, ranging from 06/01/1992 to 05/31/2022. The data were then divided into a training set (~70%) and a testing set (~30%), with the date 06/01/2013 as the dividing point.
reference: Reference: \"GARCH-Informed Neural Networks for Volatility Prediction in Financial Markets\", Section 2.8 Experiment Approach. \"For each aforementioned stock market index, approximately 7,500 days of daily closing values were captured from 06/01/1992 to 05/31/2022 through Yahoo Finance... Each data source was then divided into a training set ($\\sim 70\\%$) and a testing set ($\\sim 30\\%$), with the date 06/01/2013 as the dividing point separating the two datasets to avoid information leakage.\"
